thread.title: Liberals propose dialing back new MHA pensions, could save $5.2 million
thread.title_full: Liberals propose dialing back new MHA pensions, could save $5.2 million

author: cbc
title: Liberals propose dialing back new MHA pensions, could save $5.2 million
text:
Newfoundland and Labrador's legislature could once again make a change to the pension plans of newly-elected MHAs, with the governing Liberals pitching a plan that could see incoming politicians earn less in the long run.
In a tweet Monday morning, the Liberal caucus posted a letter from chair Randy Edmunds to Speaker Tom Osborne requesting that the legislature's management commission explore moving to a defined contribution pension plan for members elected in 2015 and beyond.
Liberal Caucus Proposes a Historic Change to Pension Plans pic.twitter.com/Hhj2MAEW10
— @GovCaucus_NL That's a change from last December, when the house voted to grandfather MHAs in the older, more lucrative plan — despite earlier recommendations that they fall under a new pension plan.
Andrew Parsons, the government house leader and a member of the management commission, said the request may have been influenced by what constituents had to say.
"Given the climate that we're in, given the concerns that were expressed, I'm sure that members of both the government caucus and the Official Opposition — all parties — heard this, listened to this and may have guided them in trying to come up with something different to to put forward," Parsons said.
In his letter, Edmunds said that the change the Liberals are now proposing could save government as much as $5.2 million, compared to the $3.6 million that would have been saved with a recommendation proposed before the vote last December.
Both the NDP and the Progressive Conservatives believe the legislature should stick with the report done by the Members Compensation Review Commission .
Timing suspicious: NDP Lorraine Michael, the NDP's house leader, questions why the Liberals are now proposing such a change.
Lorraine Michael says she is skeptical about a Liberal move to change MHA pensions. (Gary Locke/CBC)
"Now, because there's continued questions out there, they're backtracking by trying to look like, 'OK, we're doing something better than the committee,' and that really upsets me," she said.
"I think it's politics the whole way, instead of dealing with the objective work that was done by the committee."
If passed, such a change would affect 20 MHAs first elected in the 2015 general election — 19 Liberals and one Progressive Conservative — but would have no bearing on MHAs who were elected before then.
While the total savings could be $5.2 million, the actual amount depends on whether MHAs are re-elected for a second term and become eligible for pensions.
